reviewText: While this game is original, and a pretty well made challenging" (extremely difficult) platformer
date: I just can't bare to recommend it
recommended:
due to the mechanics.

Basically...each level has 2 "dimensions" that are laid on top of one another. You can move between the two dimensions most of the time as long as there is nothing in the other dimension that is blocking your way.

This isn't a problem in itself
hoursPlayed: but the way the game is designed is very frustrating...\n\nIt's hard to explain
voteText: but say you are trying to get across a spike pit with moving platforms that dissapear
helpfulPercent: what if at the very end the last platform is missing causing you certain failure? Well this game wants you to quickly move between dimension or the other map where there is a platform in mid-jump right before certain death.\n\nIt's almost like taking a leap of faith with every obstacle
votesHelpful: because there's no real way of knowing what is on the other dimension since sometimes if you switch dimensions you will just die
votesTotal: because there will be a obstacle you were unaware of like a spike trap below. So...basically
votesFunny: just to get through the level you will have to do a lot of intensional dying just to memorize where everything is in both dimensions
commentsCount: while simutaneously trying not to die and collect stuff for bonus rewards...\n\nIf there was another mechanic like seeing both maps at the same time without having to switch
column16: it would have made the game a lot better in my opinion. Leaps of faith are not my strongpoint
column17:
and certainly not a welcoming feature in such a difficult platformer.


(Another example which stumped me on the first level for a few minutes was when there was a cliff that was too high to jump on top of
column18: so I switched dimensions and the cliff got even taller with the character that jumps a bit higher
column19:
so both dimensions were seemingly unpassible. The trick is in mid jump with the character that can jump higher you are supposed to switch dimensions to the shorter cliff....  this is the type of stuff that is filled throughout the game which makes it more of a puzzle solver)

- Not to mention the bonus stages which are so increibly difficult that I'd only reccomend it to the most hardcore of platforming champions.

(Edit: One additional side note that I do not like
column20: is some of the background music is comprised of loops of bug sounds like flys / bees buzzing in your ear...very irritating if you have a headset)"

reviewText: Stonerid is a challenging 2D platformer."\nThat is putting it lightly.  This game is tough as NAILS.  There's a tutorial level explaining your abilities and the game mechanics
date: but the first proper level will cause you to do a mental double-take.  Even in the first few levels (the only ones I've played so far)
recommended: a level of precision is expected of you that isn't seen much in modern platform games.\nThe physics and handling are rather barebones
hoursPlayed: without the rich velocity control of games like Super Meat Boy
voteText: which essentially makes it less forgiving!  Thankfully one has seemingly infinite lives
helpfulPercent: starting from the beginning of the level or the last checkpoint stone you touched.  You will need them.\nThe dimension-shifting aspect can be a shot in the dark sometimes
votesHelpful: as the game will not let you teleport into a wall but it WILL let you appear touching an enemy or just over spikes.  In a more typical modern game
votesTotal: this would either not be possible or there would be some sort of visual indicator of where you'll appear on the other side
votesFunny: but that's not to say this is an oversight by the developers
commentsCount: I think you're honestly just expected to keep track of your relative position or pay the consequences.\nI don't personally care much for the graphic and sound aesthetics
column16: but your mileage may vary.\n\nAnyway tl;dr:  this would probably be a good pick for you platformer prodigies out there!   It isn't sadistically difficult to the degree of I Want To Be The Guy or Kaizo Mario
column17: and it doesn't have the "♥♥♥♥ you" traps of those or Syobon Action (Cat Mario)
column18: but at the same time it is a little too hardcore to be considered a "normal" game

reviewText: If you're way into platformers, can never get enough, and have exhausted all moderately amusing options, then you might consider looking at StoneRid.  Otherwise I would pass on the experience.  Loose controls, meaningless story, and bland design leave a distinct lack of impression with this Giana Sisters meats MeatBoy difficulty platformer.  It's competent enough, but very meh.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buUWZT9zjAA

reviewText:
Stonerid is a pretty simple and classic platform game, the gameplay is based on a world with 2 parallel dimensions where you can switch from one to another to proceed in the level. While the idea is pretty good, there are a few bugs which can negatively influence the gameplay and overall experience, I still recommend this game since its really low price and few hours of nice gameplay that it offers...

Pros:
+ Really nice graphics
+ Decent sound effects/music
+ Enjoyable background story
+ Xbox360 controller support
+ Trading cards & Achievements
+ Very low price

Cons:
- The parallel dimensions feature is not original
- Some bugs can be annoying (Checkpoints disappearing from a level, difficulty setting not keeping your choice...)
- Movement mechanics could be improved
- While in-game compatibility with controllers is great, menu navigation isn't well implemented

Classic platformer, not very original, worth the really low price
6.5/10
voteText: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Stonerid is a unique 2D platformer by indie developer Enitvare.Gameplay in Stonerid focuses on a strange gargoyle-like creature who, setting out to save the forest from spreading toxins, adventures across the land gathering up toxins and exploring the world in two planes of existence. In one world, our intrepid rocky protagonist is a somewhat benign-looking statue with enough heft to destroy enemies by jumping on them with the full brunt of his weight. In the alternate, the statue takes on a more demonic look and is lighter, enabling longer jumps but negating the capacity for combat. World-switching is done on the fly, often needing to be done mid-jump to avoid obstacles or reach platforms that only exist in one of the two realities.While the idea behind the world-switching is interesting, Stonerid has the unfortunate malady of controls that are best described as ‘muddy’. Movement feels slow and the controls are not especially responsive.The real trouble I had with Stonerid probably boils down to a perfect storm of sorts. With the controls so muddled and movement made slow and swampy, the precision needed for proper jumps and world-switching hangs mostly out of reach. The gameplay became very frustrating, which is almost too bad since the concept is sound and the art is beautiful.For the cost, the art alone may be worth checking out, but I’d certainly not recommend this title to any but the staunchest of platforming fans who are looking to support more independent developers.

reviewText: Its a very tough game. It's a simple 2d scroller that has 2 dimensions for every level. Essentially you have to die almost 30 times every level once you get to the more challenging ones. It's the only way to figure out how to complete each level. It's fun for a hour or 2 but then just gets more frustrating as times goes on.\n\ntl;dr I only bought it because I had a 90% off coupon and its probably not worth full price
voteText: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
(This review will be updated as I continue to play) Stonerid is a hard-as-nails platformer with an absolutely gorgeous art style and an interesting take on the “swapper” style mechanic, reminiscent of Giana Sisters.

The main issue with it is that you are unable to see where you are switching to, often causing you to die or do something you are unable to predict. This means you will have to learn the levels properly in order to complete them. This sounds fine in theory, but it’s hard to keep yourself going at times when you feel what you just did was in no way predictable.

Other than this, the gameplay is fantastic and very enjoyable thus far. It’s certainly not for the light-hearted, as I am no platformer veteran, but no causal either and I died many times on even the first level on easy... I dare not think what hard-mode is like.

The art style is gorgeous and really brings the game alive, and no doubt fans of games such as Super Meat Boy and Giana Sisters will thoroughly enjoy. It’s well priced and offers a great amount of fun and replayability, just be wary of the slight clunkiness of the different dimension mechanic.

reviewText: Switch back and forth between two versions of your character in order to save some important tree. Each version of you has its strenghts and weaknesses, but each version of you is in its own dimension. A sheer mountain in one dimention may be cut with a tunnel in the other dimension. Luckily, it will tell if you cannot switch to the other dimension you, rather than you instantly dying when you try to switch to the other dimension, and the grassy plain where you are is replaced by a mountain (thus killing you by teleporting to the inside of a mountain).

reviewText: with a 90% sale I bought this on a whim, without doing research first to see if its actually good and has rebindable controls. It has neither and the current keyboard config is, while not being the worst, is pretty bad. The game itself seems acceptable but it suffers from the performance issues that braid, bridge, and schein have on windows 8. Finally, there is a serious problem with the dimention switching which has been highlighted by other reviews. A similar game called fractured soul seems to have avoided that problem by allowing both dimentions to be displayed at the same time in splitscreen.

reviewText: This game is broken. It required me to teleport between two dimensions without any preview of the dimension I was about to teleport to. This meant I inadvertently teleported to a bed of spikes or missed a platform and fell to the bottom of the level purely because I wasn't psychic. The developers should know better than to make the player blindly jump from dimension to dimension. With games that have done the dual dimension mechanic correctly, like Guacamelee, there is absolutely no reason to ever try this game.\n\nBeyond that, the jump mechanic is very awkward and the animations are very bland. Even if it's on sale for half a buck, save yourself the hassle and stay away. Stonerid and Guacamelee aren't necessarily similar, but play Guacamelee instead if you haven't already because that game is phenomenal.

reviewText:
Imagine a platformer where it's easier to walk through spikes and lose health than to actually perform the necessary jumping puzzles to cross over them. This is that game. This game was about as fun as listening to hardcore Texas republicans debate the merits of non-traditional marriage.

Pros:

-It makes you feel better about your own amateur game design skills.

Cons:

-Pretty sure it was made with GameMaker, so you shouldn't pay more than a few cents for it.
-It's not fun.

reviewText:
Stonerid is an Action, Indie platformer game that, despite the reviews at mixed, is a pretty good, and difficult, game. I can't say anything bad about, yet.

In Stonerid, you are a tree, which can switch between dimensions at will, in certain places, that is. This alone is a pretty cool consept. The game tells a story of an OLD tree, whose main task is to solve the mystery of the toxic waste, now appearing unexpectedly on Atronast Mountain. This isn't the best story line ever, but it does send a positive message. The story bassically tells the story of real life as of now: a planet constantly being polluted. The only thing I dislike about this game, as I have said with others, is that your character moves around a bit too fast.

Overall, this is an okay game. I don't dislike it, and I do recommend this cheap game to everybody. It really isn't as bad as people say.

reviewText:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Puzzle platforming game.


Interface/Menu/Settings
There are 3 save slots.
You can play this game with a xbox controller.
You can play this game on fullscreen mode or windowed mode.
You are able to change the Music volume (+5 or -5 every change).
You are able to change the Sound Volume (+5 or -5 every change).
You are able to change the Ambience Volume (+5 or -5 every change).

About the game.
You are playing as a tree that has the ability to change dimensions. Whenever you are changing dimensions you are able to reach other area's and surfaces. The Dimension tree" as i call it. is faster
date:
jump higher and is able to climb so ladders. The normal tree is slow and can't jump very high but is stronger to defeat enemies.. But you have to change dimensions from time to time. Not only for completing a level but also finding some collectables or other resources. Collecting all the resources will reward you in score points.

You are able to skip Cutscenes.
Music is calm.
Graphics and scenery are fine.
There is Easy/Medium and hard mode.
There is a tutorial (Not required to do
hoursPlayed:
will show you the controls.
There are secret area's

Other things.
Game is pretty difficult and im not talking about the difficulty alone.
After dying too much
voteText:
you can't be arsed anymore about those collectables. They only give score points anyway.

-------------------

I Give this game a 7/10
"
